race.name: Gravel and Granite
race.tagline: Creek crossings and national park granite country near Tenterfield, Australia.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Australian mountains. Significant elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Australian event. Mountain terrain with remote access, moderate costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravel and Granite is a local event in NSW‚Äîmountain terrain with significant elevation. The Australian mountains are scenic, but the very small field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Australian mountain gravel race. Worth it for NSW/Australian riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to NSW‚Äîyes, it's solid. If you're traveling‚Äîskip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Australian races: Gravel Gong, Dirty Gravel.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Tenterfield has limited lodging options. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Tenterfield has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Limited organization and remote location require self-sufficiency.

logistics.explanation: Start location at 73 Manners Street with showground camping, but course redesign after a sabbatical year creates uncertainty. Organizers moved 2026 dates to May specifically because "2026 GnG will be held in May, to make the most of the cooler weather," indicating previous timing was problematic. Complete route overhaul happened because "many of the roads that we have used in previous years are now sealed."

length.explanation: At 65 miles through NSW granite country, riders face sustained challenges without survival scenarios. Jacob learned pacing discipline on early climbs: "I had to keep reminding myself not to push too hard on this climb, there was still an entire course to finish afterwards." Four feed stations at strategic intervals support the distance properly. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: The Range Rumble features creek crossings and "an absolute wall with grades in excess of 15%" at the 50km crux climb. Surface mix runs 59% gravel including fire tracks and rough service roads through Basket Swamp and Boonoo Boonoo National Parks, designed for what organizers call "Type 2 fun."

elevation.explanation: The 4,500 feet of climbing includes extended ascents and technical descents through national parks. Range Rumble course delivers "about 10km" of climbing at the 50km crux, with wall-grade pitches that matter without requiring mountaineering skills. The granite country terrain provides sustained vertical challenge. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 64¬∞F and lows of 48¬∞F, with a 50% chance of rain on any given day. Jacob rode through active snowfall: "I spent the next 15 minutes grinding in my lowest gear with snow falling off the trees as we ascended," with "muddy and sloppy" conditions creating traction challenges. The May date change specifically targets "cooler weather" after previous timing proved problematic for rider comfort. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: NSW granite country elevations stay within manageable bands while delivering mountain character. The 4,500 feet total gain indicates significant vertical through Great Dividing Range terrain without alpine complications. Creek crossings and extended climbing occur at modest absolute altitudes. Modest altitude compared to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

adventure.explanation: Basket Swamp Bash creek crossing and sweeping national park views deliver backcountry character. The Range Rumble winds through protected granite country where organizers emphasize focus "on the adventure and the landscape around you" rather than pure racing. Creek depths vary with conditions, adding weather-dependent adventure elements.

prestige.explanation: Sixth edition of a regional event where organizers explicitly welcome "gravel bikes, mountain bikes, e-bikes, and adaptive bikes." Caitlin Reid emphasizes it's "organised to be as welcoming as possible to all riders, regardless of their FTP," with prizes only for fastest two per category, confirming participation over competitive depth.

race_quality.explanation: Proper aid station placement every 17-20km with "food, water, and first aid supplies" shows solid organization basics. However, course evolution happened because "many of the roads that we have used in previous years are now sealed," requiring completely new 2025 routes after taking a sabbatical year.

experience.explanation: Race village features "DJs, food trucks, and local beer and wine at the Tenterfield Showgrounds" with Friday night main street festivities. Jacob experienced "lively atmosphere with the live band" and electric dawn start energy, but the event's sabbatical year and complete course overhaul indicate experience consistency challenges.

community.explanation: Jacob felt "the electricity at the dawn start" as "300 riders left under police escort out of downtown Wausau," with family-friendly weekend atmosphere and inclusive philosophy welcoming all bike types. The Saddlers MTB Club organizes this for trail network funding, but required course redesign shows organizational transitions.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 50-100 riders, todd Meerdink worried that losing the lead group early would turn "this race would quickly turn into just a group ride," indicating thin competitive depth. The explicit welcome for adaptive bikes and e-bikes alongside traditional categories prioritizes inclusivity over racing field strength in this regional NSW event. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: The NSW Government site lists it as 'free' which either means spectating or they're underselling their own race entry fees. If registration is actually cheap, 65 miles of Australian granite country for minimal cash outlay delivers decent bang for buck. Just don't expect premium race services at budget pricing.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $75-100 AUD. Multi-bike welcome policy means riders can use existing mountain bikes rather than buying gravel-specific equipment, with Todd Meerdink successfully using 40mm tires on technical sections. Rural Tenterfield location requires travel from major cities, while Todd's Camelback strategy shows self-sufficient riders can minimize aid station dependencies. Higher total cost than Badlands.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: Gravel and Granite gravel race Tenterfield

videos.title: The Tenterfield Gravel n Granite 2023 Through Our Eyes
videos.description:
The 2023 Gravel n Granite ride in Tenterfield. The second running of this event starts in the Showgrounds, and heads out of town over Mt Mackenzie, to then do a big loop on some nice quiet country bitumen, and gravel roads.

Thank you to all involved in making this event possible!

Check out Gravel n Granite on Facebook here - https://www.facebook.com/GravelnGranite

videos.title: GRAVEL AND GRANITE CYCLING EVENT - TENTERFIELD 2023
videos.description: This years 2023 Edition 2 of Gravel n Granite in beautiful Tenterfield. March 4, 2023. What a smashing day.

videos.title: Gravel n Granite - 2025
videos.description: Set in the stunning region of Tenterfield, the 2025 events was a journey through rugged and spectacular landscapes, while testing riders' endurance, skill and spirit!
videos.transcript:
[Music]
The gravel and granite is really a tough
gravel riding event. We've sent these
riders off onto trails that range from,
you know, gravel roads to natural gravel
fire trail surfaces and I guess that's
the essence of the gravel and granite.
It's a tough adventure type ride.
Ladies and gentlemen, your attention
please. In three, two, one, roll away.
So, the different courses this year, we
have the Rain Rumble 91 km, the
Wellington Rocks course, 66 km, and the
Basket Swamp Bash, which is our short
course adaptive ride, 38 km back into
town. The course today was very
challenging. Bit carnage, few crashes,
lots of cramps, lots of injuries. That
all makes for good riding. There's
nothing wrong with the challenge.
So, we done the Curry's Dash today. It
was 11Ks. It's a good little course for
kids.
It was a really good family friendly.
It was very fun. Very bumpy.
It's really nice to actually do a ride
as a family together. So, that was
pretty special that we could do that
today. Attention field.
It was an awesome weekend. Really
wellrun event. Very inclusive. Nothing's
a drama, mate. I love it. I still got a
grin on me face just thinking about it.
It's been one of the best years so far
and it will only get bigger and better.
I think
it truly is a a magical place to to
ride.

videos.title: Gravel n Granite, Tenterfield // I Think I Smiled the Whole Way
videos.description:
#gravelevent
What a way to see the countryside! An awesome event at Tenterfield with almost 600 people enjoying the Granite Belt and a fun but tough day in the saddle.

Join us as we travel the east coast of Australia, training and racing. We‚Äôre living proof that anyone can compete in triathlons. You just need to give it a shot.

Cheers,
Amanda & Tim

videos.curation_reason: Excellent first-person ride experience with detailed course insights and highest view count.

quotes.text: The Kildare Road has just been bitumized it's very slippery, so even though you are going to want to hammer it down kill their Road you're gonna have to back it off a bit it's very very slippery. The other thing we've got Causeway they can be slippery and they'll have water over them so take it easy.

It's stunning the geography out here is just so extraordinarily different and beautiful, the Rolling Hills and all the gravel and all the granite Mounds they're just beautiful to see. I kept wanting to stop and take photos.

The scenery around there was absolutely stunning, every time you went around a corner you just saw more hills and you didn't know where to look, just beautiful views left and right with a lot of gravel and water crossings as well.
